Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: A comparison with the Red Scare of the 1950's would be more apt. These unsubstantiated allegations that Trump operatives are actually working for Russian agents have been floating around for months. Meanwhile, despite all the intercepted communications, no one has ever been arrested or charged. It would appear that journalists are as fond of conspiracy theories as any of the fantasy prone out there in the wilds of cyberspace. There are actual conspiracies. Yet, making unsubstantiated allegations is not proof. The purpose of rumours is to sow doubt. Even if nothing ever comes of this, and it probably won't, at least some people will always wonder if Trump and his colleagues are in league with the Russians to undermine Western democracy. Once someone is accused, it is hard to clear your name. That is the whole point of politically motivated rumours.

Comment: Alceste, you describe the age-old tradition of judges interpreting the law, which they have done, um, forever, and you pretend that is their "clarifying" the law.

No, the correct word for what judges do is that they "interpret" the law, not "clarify" the law. Those two verbs have different meanings.

And since the period after the birth of the Charter, in the 1980s, the Charter has been, as I said, the measure of all measures for Canadian laws, including those arising from older layers of common law if they were the basis for government action (as is the case for the journalism challenge). Our courts have been that way now for decades.

And so in our post-1980's nation, the judges in the present 2017 case will be doing precisely what I stated: They will judge whether the law over-reaches and violates a fundamental right in the Charter.

Comment: On August 19, 2016, Manafort left the Trump campaign amid media reports about his previous work for a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine, including allegations he received millions of dollars in payments.

That same day, Manafort created a holding company called Summerbreeze LLC. Several weeks later, a document called a UCC filed with the state of New York shows that Summerbreeze took out a $3.5 million loan on Manafort's home in the tiny beach enclave of Bridgehampton.


Manafort's company never paid $36,000 in taxes that would be due on the loan.


A spokesperson for Spruce Capital said the loan came from an unnamed independent broker.
If that seems like a nice beach house payoff to the guy who fronted Trump’s campaign from sources that would rather keep their identities hidden … that’s exactly what it is. And it’s just the first step in a scheme to give Manafort an even bigger payday.

Comment: I spent a year studying NOAA figures on climates in various places around the US before I decided to retire here. I know about the hot summers and the low precipitation months. I also know about the wet, usually chilly but not snowy winters. And I was here for part of the ice storm last winter, when everybody I met told me how weird it was. I know quite a bit, actually.

This is the worst smoke season, apparently, for 30 years. And I'd be willing to bet that monthly or even seasonal temperature records are being set this summer. The average is 15 days above 90F a year. How many this year? And the fire season keeps getting longer. We're experiencing a drought, apparently, as well, and immediately after a record snow pack. I know for sure that longer fire seasons have been linked to climate change, as has the worsening of bark beetle infestations in the Rockies and Cascades. 

We're seeing what climate change SHOULD look like in the PNW.

Comment: I agree completely with one of the main points made by the author:  abstinence is not the end goal, it is only the ticket for admission on the road to reclaiming ones life.  I have seen dozens of people in AA meetings who had been sober for several years and were nowhere near being on the road to recovery, notwithstanding their purported practice of the 12 steps.

Unless the author meant to include this in a broad interpretation of "pain", he left out one very common issue with substance abusers - mental health problems.  In my case it was clinical depression which I was self-medicating, and I have seen the same in many others.

The personal work in recovery never produces instant results and sometimes seems to be a futile waste of time.  As one AA wag said "What I need is more patience, and I want it right now".  One has to forget about any expected result and simply focus on the now.

Comment: Jill Pinkerton, you talked to whomever you talked to. Fine. But abortion in itself is neither a good nor a bad action. It all depends on the interpretation of the pregnant woman. It can be a very bad decision to refrain from abortion in certain circumstances.

Nor is it persuasive to describe abortion as "the killing of a human being." Yes, it is the killing of a certain kind of being who is certainly human. But it is always misleading at best, more usually just plain wrong, to speak of a "human being," as though this were an independent being such as a human infant. There is always a woman attached to that being, and it is always wrong to speak of that being without giving due regard to the necessary presence of the woman.

I too was adopted, from a Catholic agency run by nuns, at age 2 months. And I am firmly in favor of abortion rights for women. There is no other just or humane option.

Comment: It occurs to me that liberals can be authoritarian, too.
That said, I don't think the US bishops, as a group, were hardliners about HV, especially in the ten years that remained to Paul VI. (JPII changed everything, including the makeup of the hierarchy.) The US Bishops' pastoral letter responding to HV, 'Human Life in Our Day', was a moderate affirmation both of the teaching of HV and of the conscience rights of married couples. There were many priests who wrestled with HV as confessors, and many bishops who tried conscientiously to help them do it. I knew one very conservative priest who left ministry because he thought HV was wrong, but he could see no wiggle room for himself as a confessor. Many people remember or know about Cardinal O'Boyle's confrontation with the Catholic University theologians. I don't think O'Boyle was representative of the US hierarchy. I think it's important to note that he was acting not as Archbishop of Washington but as Chancellor of the University.

Comment: Japan has their share of budget issues, maybe not as big cost overruns as ours. But I think you have the biggest issue tangentially correct: we have no prior experience. So we have to scramble and get new talent together plus have them manage a design build package at the same time. It's no wonder we see the lunacy of major issues falling through the cracks. I think at least we could have prevented compounding issues like that by getting away from design build. So if J-Rail said they are doing design build for their new maglev, I know they have the ability to manage the deal much better than us because they have a mature functioning entity. Another example using local entities: Hon-BOWS on going sewage/potable water upgrades. Huge undertakings, but not quite as large as the rail. Why aren't we seeing major failures? How about because there is a functional mature entity already in place. I'm sure Hon-BOWS has it's issues, but it really helps to have a mature entity doing projects.

Comment: Non Profit organizations are required to file a tax return each year, yes, even though they are tax exempt. 
Non Profits are required to file a form 990. The type of 990's depending on the size of the agencies budget. If an agency has a total annual budget under $50,000, they can file a 990-N
https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/form-990-series-which-forms-do-exempt-organizations-file-filing-phase-in

An agency filing a 990-N or EZ, can't have too high of a payroll as that is part of the total budget.
All of their details are public information.  You can easily see what your favorite non profits are paying staff. A non profit that pays a person over $50,000 a year must declare that individual on the 990.
Part VIII is what you are looking for.

https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=&state%5Bid%5D=HI&ntee%5Bid%5D=&c_code%5Bid%5D=
You can further limit the search to "Human Services" and 501(c)(3) to see homeless service providers

Comment: "there is no peak even close to of been reached in oil yet"

For over 150 years we have become increasingly dependent on petroleum. Although we've moved to unconventional sources of liquid fuel, it's conventional, pump-able oil that still accounts for about 80% of our "all liquids" supply.
Conventional oil production peaked more than a decade ago, a few years after Mexico, UK, Norway Malaysia and Denmark peaked.
Global all-liquids production is around 97 mbpd and you are correct: it's still increasing. But roughly 10% of that is natural gas liquids, not crude oil. Another 1.6 mbpd come from biofuels.

Sure, we have plenty of bitumen, but 80% of it can only be extracted using in-situ methods. Meanwhile, the decline rate for post-peak producers is 5-7% per year and discovery rates are the lowest in over half a century.

Our descendants will not be using as much petroleum as we are. They will struggle to produce affordable fuel from in-situ bitumen... that's about all that will be left.

Comment: The MLS average sales price is not to be trusted as a price indicator. The Teranet National Bank 11-city composite  HPI showed a 0.8% monthly decline in September, the first such decline since January 2016. Hamilton showed a 1.9% drop, its first monthly drop since February 2016, and Toronto a 2.7% drop, following on a 0.4% drop in August. There were also monthly declines in other Greater Golden Horseshoe cities not included in the composite index. We could be in the third month of a housing price correction for the GGH that might well take Canada into recession.

Comment: Weather is not climate, but climate steadily influences weather. 

We feel weather every day, every season, and it is both variable and local. It takes science, not anecdote, to discern climate change. 

Increased snowfall under some circumstances is actually a predicted outcome of climate change, because warmer air holds more water. If it's warmer than historic levels, but still cold enough in the mountains to make snow, the result is jumbo snowpack.

If it's warmer, but right on the bubble between snow and rain, then we get a lot of freezing rain. 

A couple of years before, it was warmer, but just _above_ the threshold to make snow, even up in the mountains. So what snow did fall, got melted away by rain away early on, and we had a whole different kind of drought... from this summer's simple above-normal temperatures and below-normal rainfall.

Comment: True, I-25 does more to split Denver itself than I-70. All of west Denver is divided from downtown. 

270 was built for a more direct path to and from Boulder to Stapleton. It was also a way to relieve traffic at the mousetrap. As was 76, but as a shortcut to 76 going out towards Brighton and northeast Colorado to drive to and from I-70 going through the mountains.

Most people probably aren't aware Washington St. was basically the highway heading north of Denver before I-25, and Colfax was the main east-west corridor before I-70. 

The examples of KC, St. Louis and Indy highlight why Denver is hardly unique with an interstate within city limits (not quite through downtown, yes). Early Denver leaders built a rail line to Cheyenne to connect to the Trans-Continental line, or Denver becomes irrelevant. I-70 was built to move troops and goods easily from east-west without bypassing through Wyoming or New Mexico. They were necessary for Denver to grow into the planned "world class city".

Comment: From the article: "While the debt isn’t high enough to merit a downgrade according to the DBRS ratings agency, Mr. Sousa’s decision to focus on increased spending rather than debt repayment means the province has little fiscal room to respond to an economic shock"

Good to see at least an off-hand mention in the mainstream media of what I've been saying for years.

Let's face, given global economic conditions a monkey could balance Ontario's budget right now.  The global economy has been relatively strong for a while and, with low oil prices pummelling the Canadian dollars and a strong U.S. economy it is a pretty trivial task to balance the budget this year.

The problem is that economic cycles are, well, cyclical.  Since WWII we've been running pretty consistently on about 9 to 10 year economic cycles from one recession to the next, and the last recession started 8 and a half years ago.

Comment: Hmmm... Your numbers are all off. Consider these two statements from your article:

"the worker picks up 150 gallons of pigeon dung annually" 
"One pigeon can produce 25 pounds of guano per year"

1 gallon of water weighs 8 pounds.
I gallon of feces weighs between 1 and 4 pounds, depending on the water content.

Lets take the high end of this ratio, and we'll use the weight of water in this measurement:

150 (gallons) x 8 (lbs) = 1200 lbs

1200 (lbs) ÷ 25 (lbs of guano p/year, p/bird) = 48 (birds)

So, you are telling me that Fairbanks has about 48 pigeons... or you are inflating the production of guano.

Since I own a pet pigeon, I'd have to say the latter. My pigeon doesn't have scrounge for food, and gets to eat as much as she wants. She has never pooped that quantitiy in a year's time. Her fecal matter amounts to a couple of ounces per week - less that 8 pounds per year, which is a lot less than one homeless junkie excretes on your side-walks in a week... or a huskie, or a bear...

Comment: Our governments will need to be careful about getting too greedy on this one.  The black market for marijuana is already well established and if the government tries to charge too high a price and make limit availability (say, for example, by only allowing the sale through a small number of government-run stores throughout the Province) then the black market may offer a more attractive product to consumers than the legal market offers.

Keep in mind that buyers are almost certain not to be charged for buying in the black market, so only the dealers and producers have any risk here.  If taxation is too high there will be substantial profit margin available for them to undercut the legal channels.

We don't see this too much with alcohol because taxation on booze isn't all that high and distribution isn't all that bad.

Comment: I have a few ETFs, but they are a small part of my portfolio.  Ditto mutual funds....  Most of my equity holdings are individual shares.  The transaction fees are only trading commissions and, since I’m a ‘buy and hold’ investor, the fees are minimal and under my control.  To me, they represent to cost I pay for the full-service broker’s research dept.  I have no interest in doing detailed company research, so I’m willing to pay for for that service.  If I opted for mutual funds, lots of ETFs, or a managed portfolio, I’d pay a lot more in fees!   The use of computer algorithms in ETFs worry me as a potential contributor to/cause of ‘flash crashes’  so I think they could become a negative factor in the market.  The fundamental problem that gives rise to all the fund-type products is that too many people do not take responsibility to managing their finances!   ETFs seem to be the latest product that allows people to think they are managing their money smartly while actually ignoring it!

Comment: That is interesting- in high school I gave up my lunch hour almost every year so that I could take extra classes in a semester and graduate early, accelerating the time when I could support myself and then go on to pay for my own college.  I tried to never have a first period class, and would happily pack the rest of my day.  I ate lunch while I learned, which is a fairly common practice in the workplace as well. I don't believe that impacting cognition and brain development during a crucial growth period is worth forcing kids to wake up early.  It doesn't teach them perseverance, it just makes them tired.  Imagine how much more driven they could be if they could think.  Teenagers are in a different growth phase than adults, so it is false to equate them vs an adult waking up early.  Kids getting themselves to school on time is what teaches them responsibility,  not forcing them to do it at zero dark thirty for no reason, particularly when it is obviously bad for theiron development.

Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: The term economic terrorism or financial terrorism is strictly defined to indicate an attempt at economic destabilization by a group. Economic terrorism is defined in the following terms:

Contrary to "economic warfare" which is undertaken by states against other states, "economic terrorism" would be undertaken by transnational or non-state actors. This could entail varied, coordinated and sophisticated or massive destabilizing actions in order to disrupt the economic and financial stability of a state, a group of states or a society (such as market oriented western societies or economies) or a trading exchange for ideological, monetary or religious motives.

These actions, if undertaken, may be violent or not. They could have either immediate effects or carry psychological effects which in turn have economic consequences.

Source from Wikipedia

Comment: After decades of capital funding, and hundreds of millions of dollars poured into failed systems, ADEC has belated recognized that there was a problem. Good.

Unfortunately, this system seems to have the same flaws that have doomed other attempts at rural sanitation: complexity, high maintenance (related to complexity), and high cost, both the initial capital cost and the maintenance cost. The reason that many rural systems have not totally collapsed is that there is a system of state-funded Rural Maintenance Workers, highly-skilled mechanics stationed in rural hubs around the state. RMWs have rescued untold systems from failure and, particularly in the winter, from destruction. Given the state's fiscal situation, who knows how long the RMWs will continue to have jobs?

Elegant, complex, and expensive owner-maintained systems are simply not viable. Flush-haul may be the best we can do, but even that may be too expensive for many.

But good luck in your search.

Comment: In a nutshell the problem we have is that in Canada we do not have free speech. Do not for one minute think that you have the same right to free speech that our American neighbours have protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. Oh, what is this you say? We have Freedom of Expression Guaranteed by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. NO you do not and why not? Well...

Trudeau senior was very cagey when he crafted that Charter. Sure section 2(b) of the Charter says "Freedom of thought, belief, opinion and expression..." but the old curmudgeon stuck in a clause that could take it away. That's right, the infamous weasel clause or section 1. Believe me the Americans never would have stood for that but we had that bamboozled right by us.  Section 1 lets the courts take your freedoms away and as long as the 9 Santa Suites in Ottawa says it is for the good of a free & democratic society "POOF" your rights disappear. Bye bye free speech.

Comment: I don't know that there are, of necessity, gymnastics to "never-change".  I like the fact that math never changes, nor chemistry.  We discover more about these but the foundation of each is set.  
Your comment about "lying to God" is very much in line with Dom Scipoli, Francis de Sales, and Teresa of Avila; I very much appreciate the sentiment.  Far from being a vice, wanting that for others is a great virtue.  My belief in the subject, however, is that regardless of what we think God is saying to us, the definitive manner in which He speaks in the world today is through His Church.  Only on that authority do we have any knowledge of God in Scripture, or in our lives.  That said, I will concede that too many on both "right" and "left" do not know that there exists both an infallible and fallible magisterium.  The former we accede to from faith, the second from obedience to authority if good conscience does not dictate otherwise.  That's a new discussion, however.
Thanks, again.

Comment: http://labor.alaska.gov/lss/forms/sum-wh-act-1.pdf is the Wage and Hour Act summary, where you'll find listed exemptions:

"An independent taxicab driver who establishes the driving area and hours, who contracts on a flat rate basis for use of the cab, permit or dispatch services, and who is compensated solely by the customers served;"

Many cab companies in Fairbanks try to dictate "driving area and hours" to drivers and have refused to lease a cab to those unwilling to play along. They view the whole "independent contractor" thing as a liability / tax dodge and effectively treat their drivers as employees

As for the state, this exemption passed into law in 1993. While the taxi business did lobby for it, I know many folks who served in or worked for the legislature at the time. I was told that the Teamsters Local 959, which had fallen rather far in the post-Jesse Carr era, was trying to organize cab drivers in Anchorage and there was concern on their part about that.

Comment: "Walking away from your stranded vehicle is a no-no for anyone."
JJ,  while that is generally good advice there are no hard and fast rules here-- from a long life driving forest roads I can assure you  there are times walking back from a stranded  vehicle is the best solution and it would have been ignorant to just sit there.  It depends on the situation,  weather, location, the person, probability  of rescue, etc.
It also helps to  carry tools, including a shovel, and have some savvy about how to deal with rough roads-- I once had a girlfriend-- a log truck driver's daughter-- who got us unstuck on a lonely mountain gravel road  in the Umpqua by using a clever technique I would never have thought of.

Comment: I'm not going to comment about the killer or the victim, just the milieu.

We've always had social signaling, where people intentionally provoke or solicit attention and validation from the people around them, but the rise of social media in general, and Facebook in particular, has created a native market for attention that simply didn't exist 20 years ago. Someone looking to engage in an extreme act to garner notoriety was limited by the limits of media back then, but now they can publish in an instant, have viral reach in less than 24 hours, and become sensations, literally overnight.

We've created the perfect vehicle for people who engage in these kinds of acts - near instant celebrity. This won't be the first or the last, unfortunately.

Comment: Thank you, Doug Saunders, for this very insightful piece! I always enjoy your articles, but this one hit me personally. I grew up in England and came to Canada in 1971. I chose Canada because it was easier to get into than the U.S. and because I spoke French and found Quebec interesting. 

In my early years in Canada, I thought of moving to the U.S., but I've come to appreciate Canada as an incredibly diverse country, free from the hangups of having to be "great" or powerful, yet making huge strides in social progress in a relatively quiet and peaceful way. You beautifully summarized, and gave historical context to, most of the reasons I find Canada a very exciting place to be.

A fitting start to 2017!

Comment: It is not a question of whether the county can tax enough to give employees what they want.  Of course they can.  The question is what is reasonable pay.  This cannot be answered by referencing pay to other counties as all counties face zero competition or need to be frugal.  Pay should be determined by a combination of comparison with similar private for profit company compensation (real competition sets wages scale) and direct experience of how much pay is necessary to hire new employees able with reasonable training to do the jobs.

It is widely believed that county pay exceeds reasonable expectation for work performed.  If this is indeed the case.  We must not shy away from accepting a strike and waiting until county employees either accept reasonable wages or quit so that new and better employees can be hired.

This one Lane county voter suggests that the county lock the doors for at least one month once the unions strike.  Think of the possible park improvements enabled.

Comment: Looking at some of the earliest writings of the Church, such as the Didache (~70 AD) and the 1st Epistle of Clement to the Corinthians (~92AD), as well as the New Testament writings, it would appear the church by that time had a fairly uniform organizational & liturgical structure. This included bishops (episkopoi, “overseers”), priests (presbuteroi, “elders”) & deacons (diakonoi, “servants) By the mid 2nd century, the basic NT Canon had been established, as noted in the Muratorian Canon (~160 AD).

So within about 70 years after the Resurrection, there was an organization communicating across the Mediterranean. Not the type of an organization waiting for the end of the world.

While the persecution by Nero was bloody, it was thankfully brief. So from about 70 to 90 AD, no persecutions are noted, until for some reason Domitian initiated a series of persecutions.

Comment: I have read at least some of those pieces and agree there are many good ideas.

I think tax incentives are great levers to pull. Simpler measures are things like scrapping home owner grants. That program costs the province nearly $1B each year. Even if it's only a few hundred $ per household, why is giving this cash to people with an asset worth up to $1.6M a priority? Similarly, reel in the provincial property tax deferral program (empty nesters sitting on a house worth millions don't need a coddling property tax policy). Also, scrap the first time buyer home owner down payment loan program, a ridiculous market interference that only serves to push prices up further (and was derided by the CMHC).

On a bigger level, I like Josh Gordon's plan for a progressive higher property tax with income offsets. So if you work locally, your tax burden won't change. But if you're not declaring income here, you pay a lot more tax (obviously there's more to it than that, but that's it generally).

Comment: FreshOutDaTrap et al: I think some are digging themselves into a hole on this topic without understanding relevant facts. New immigrants who arrive through the normal immigration process are pre-screened for health concerns and it's therefore logical that they tend to be generally healthier upon arrival than are native-born Canadians. However, studies done by relevant authorities, including Stats Can, have shown that the new immigrant health advantage quickly wears off, and this is particularly so for those of lower socio-economic status and those who lack English or French language proficiency. Also, refugee health outcomes in Canada are poorer than those experienced in the broader immigrant population. 

http://tvo.org/article/current-affairs/shared-values/canadian-immigrants-arrive-healthy-but-that-doesnt-lastheres-why

Comment: The last Prime Minister who could barely speak or read or write or understand French was John Diefenbaker. Though in truth, Im not too sure whether Lester Pearson was fluently bilingual. Perhaps another reader might advise. But since 1968...this nearly a half century, our PrimeMinisters have been bilingual. Jean Chretien may not have had perfect english or even perfect French, but he sure as hell knew what was going on in both languages. 

There is of course nothing to prevent  a person from pursuing the leadership of a political party or of the country being fluent in only one official language.But in this day and age, i think it would be very difficult for that person to win. For very valid reasons. It doesnt mean that this person cant contribute, be for example, a senior advisor or member of parliament. But just as with the Governor General, the Prime Minister should be able to speak to all Canadians, and both listen and hear what people are saying in two official languages.

Comment: Many thanks to Lara Yamada for her outstanding analysis and compassionate consideration of these important issues.  12 years ago I published my own analysis, which might be of interest:
"Life and Death -- Moral Shades of Gray"
http://tinyurl.com/6dwry

Should an individual have a right to choose death for himself or for a close relative unable to make the choice? Should society be able to prevent such a choice, or to keep someone alive who prefers to die? Should society be able to require the killing of criminals or even of merely unproductive or inconvenient people? Should society, or individual people, have any right to make decisions about life and death; or should such decisions be left in the hands of God? There is a spectrum of stages of human life, from before conception to after death; and the larger moral issues reverberate in different ways at different stages.  It might be that all beings (e.g. animals) have fundamental rights in proportion to their level of sentience.

Comment: Here's  my "unexpected" Girl Guides lesson:
In May 2010, Girl Guides Canada celebrates its 100 year anniversary.
A rally was to be held at Ontario Place.  
One evening in March, I heard about this rally, and surprised that my daughter had not brought home a permission slip,  I asked a leader if they were planning to attend. I was told that there were not sufficient leaders, based on the required ratio for the rally. 
Not wanting the troop to miss out, I immediately volunteered my wife and I. Full credit to local leadership: plans were drawn up, a bus chartered, and permission forms sent home with the girls. 
As few days before the rally, a leader came to the house to speak with my wife. She explained that while my volunteerism was to be commended, unfortunately, I could not attend: district GCG council was looking over the final arrangements, and vetoed my participation because I was a male. 

The CGC does not  hold the moral high ground on this or any other issue.

Comment: I don't think that the world is "normalizing the irrational more and more every day".  I think that people continue to struggle with the same impulses that drove them from time immemorial.  Part of the problem is that the institutions that ought to be guiding us towards a moral end are not working as they ought to be doing.  Once the Catholic church in the US became aligned with those who have wealth, the Church stopped seeing the needs of the have-nots as paramount.  when John Paul 2, decided that liberation theology was bad, he threw out the baby with the bath water and, despite all of his compassionate words threw the poor under the wheels of the bus of greed and consumption.  
It seems to me that, instead of bemoaning the situation, it would be more prudent to organize small activist groups on the ground to get people involved in local political action.  That is how we can prevent what happened in Congress.

Comment: Uninformed nonsense, StewartBrian.  

Dennis Edney has represented him for 13 years largely unpaid.  The original lawsuit set damages at $100,000, because he had only been in Guantanamo a matter of months, not all of the Charter violations had happened, they had no documentary proof of Canadian officials handing over their interview transcripts to the Americans, and there had been no judicial decisions confirming what had happened.

It was only in 2014 - after 'some' of the documentary evidence had been handed over, and the SCC had confirmed the massive Charter violations, and Khadr had spent over a decade in prison, that the damage claim was amended.

The shame is that the Harper government was too bloody-minded to negotiate his return and a settlement of damages at a time when it would have cost Canadians a fraction of the eventual cost.

Comment: William:  I've been a hunter all my life.  Started in the 1950s with my Grandfather.  I still own guns, though I no longer hunt. Usually, they're very careful with their firearms and are not a threat to anyone.  I am concerned with the proliferation of semi-automatic, large magazine rifles among the general population.  I am concerned with the ease with which virtually anyone can buy a gun today.....legit market and black market.  I feel there are some very reasonable efforts to try to keep firearms away from dangerous individuals.....via expanded background checks and the use of the "no-fly" and/or watch list....the NRA has consistently opposed all of these.  I don't see that as reasonable....

I don't want to "take away" everyone's guns.  However, lets be frank..some people shouldn't have them

Comment: Hi Doctor D., accurate health and mortality records for First Nations people weren't kept until recently and certainly not prior to European contact after which many historians estimate that about 90% of the native populations of the the Americas died from diseases imported by Eurasian immigrants. For all we know, their original tribal lifestyle contributed to longer lifespans, at least in some cases, but there's no way to know. 

Regardless, my point is that a cultural tradition can be whatever anyone says it is but that doesn't carry much weight in the marketplace which can also be termed a "cultural tradition" going back centuries. Under our current socio-economic and legal system, the individual is primarily responsible for their housing situation and career choices. I'm not aware of any fairer way to approach it in a free society. People make a lifestyle choice when they live and work in expensive urban areas but ignore saner alternatives. It's not like they're starved for choice.

Comment: There will not be a book published this fall more urgent, important, or controversial than The Dangerous Case of Donald Trump, the work of 27 psychiatrists, psychologists and mental health experts to assess President Trump’s mental health.
They had come together last March at a conference at Yale University to wrestle with two questions.
One was on countless minds across the country: “What’s wrong with him?”
The second was directed to their own code of ethics: “Does Professional Responsibility Include a Duty to Warn” if they conclude the president to be dangerously unfit?
Their decision: “We respect the rule, we deem it subordinate to the single most important principle that guides our professional conduct: that we hold our responsibility to human life and well-being as paramount.”
Hence, this profound, illuminating and discomforting book undertaken as “a duty to warn.”

Comment: Federal Child Safety Lock Act of 2005 effective April 24 2006 

 In October 2005, Congress passed and President Bush signed into law legislation making it unlawful for any licensed importer, manufacturer or dealer to sell or transfer any handgun unless the transferee is provided with a secure gun storage or safety device.
A “secure gun storage or safety device” is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(34) as:
(A) a device that, when installed on a firearm, is designed to prevent the firearm from being operated without first deactivating the device;
(B) a device incorporated into the design of the firearm that is designed to prevent the operation of the firearm by anyone not having access to the device; or
C) a safe, gun safe, gun case, lock box, or other device that is designed to be or can be used to store a firearm and that is designed to be unlocked only by means of a key, a combination, or other similar means.
Dr Forester wants a law which already exists.  He needs to find  a new hobby.

Comment: That's just absurd.

People _do_ enter and immigrate to the US legally.  Lots of people, every day.  You don't hear sad stories about how these people are torn away from their families, because they did it the _right_ way.

The fact that successive governments in the US looked the other way rather than enforcing their own laws doesn't mean the law _shouldn't_ be enforced. Comment: Nobody "models" individual storms using GCM's. The granularity is not there, although it's better than it was. I don't think you really get this basic distinction. Predicting individual weather events involves different inputs, data sources and means from the modelling of global circulation by climatologists.  

Climate scientists rarely attribute individual weather events to GW without a great number of caveats and reservations. It was an epoch-making event when Kerry Emmanuel--the dean of hurricane scientists--came right out and said that TS Sandy was as bad as it was because Atlantic waters off NJ were freakishly warm. Likewise, the conclusion that the Syrian droughts that precipitated (sic) the civil war bore global warming fingerprints, an epochal event, and published in the Proceedings.  

I'm not sure I understand what we're arguing about.  There's very little uncertainty in the scientific understanding of the mechanisms of  MMGW. There's much less consensus about impacts.

Government healthcare.

Comment: James Reeves - Again I challenge you to provide specific quotes from legitimate research papers that prove your claims that drinking fluoridated water lowers IQ, causes ADHD, or causes any other health problems.  I have read those papers, and I have never seen where the authors --- many of whom are devout fluoridation opponents --- actually make those claims.  Provide the specific conclusions in context and then there will be something to discuss.

For example, there is absolutely no scientific reference I am aware of that claims "Fluoridation causes enamel damage in 41% of all children".  Provide a specific citation that proves that all dental fluorosis is "enamel damage".  

The fact is that essentially all of the dental fluorosis in fluoridated communities is mild to very mild and actually protects the teeth from decay.  The noticeable, moderate or severe dental fluorosis is caused by ingestion of toothpaste or other fluoride-containing compounds - not drinking water.

Comment: So, there's a few things to unpack here. Exit polls, that is what happens when people think unweighted raw data is the correct data. When doing exit polls, some people are more likely to answer than others. Older people are the least likely, people of color are less likely, young people are the most likely, so demographically, the raw data would oversample Bernie's demographic. After they get the raw data, they have to compare it to the actual voting demographics and adjust to fit the the voting population, not the answering population. 

As to the studies by Berkeley and Stanford math department. There's no such thing. There is a report by a couple of students, not professors, not researchers, not the college. The authors did not present it as a study by the college, but Bernie supporters misrepresented their "report" as something official which is pretty reprehensible since it damages their reputation and will lead people to think they lie. Comment: Haha, Jeff, low level staffer indeed. I'm not a staffer but I do have economic creds, so I know of which I speak.

In response to your comment, which apart from the little dig at me is quite legitimate, the economy works as much if not more on signals. This was Keynes' insight, that he termed "animal spirits."

We've seen that with the DOW rising on the expectations of Trump lowering corporate taxes, and now stagnating with the growing uncertainty. Likewise, the expectation of GDP increases due to promised fiscal stimulus becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy under the right circumstances. So you don't actually need shovels to hit the dirt, all you need is the expectation that they will.

Ironically, now that we no longer expect the metaphorical shovels, as they are not needed, the expectation of sustained growth without inflationary pressures should create its own momentum.

So I say again, thank you Mr. Trudeau!

Comment: Generally good news, though perhaps somewhat tempered by the fact that much of this "growth" is just an echo of the decline in the second quarter from the fires in Alberta.

Take the effects of those fires out of the picture and Q2 looks less bad while Q3 seems less impressive.

On the whole we're seeing 1.3% real GDP growth year-over-year, which is best described as "slow growth".  Given global conditions, which are reasonably solid overall but with some weakness in commodities, slow growth is probably about as expected for Canada.  As much as politicians will try to claim one thing or another with this, the economy probably would have grown at pretty much this exact same rate regardless of who was in charge or what policies they put in place (baring anything really extreme).

Comment: This Dark Act bill that Tulsi Gabbard and Brian Schatz rightly voted against and Mazie Hirono wrongly voted for is a bill that would preempt any state labeling laws that have been passed, and it allows for the labeling to be done with a website link, QR or bar code vs. a clear label right on the product that says “this product contains GMO ingredients.” This makes it very difficult for a consumer to know what is in the food they are buying, which is their right. The Center for Food Safety argued that “QR codes discriminate against low-income, rural and elderly people, as well as a disproportionately high number of minority Americans that don’t have smartphones or Internet access.” 

The bill also exempts a number of different genetically modified foods from even being included, so all these foods won't require labeling at all. Even the FDA, which does not support GMO labeling, has said this bill contains so many exceptions and different standards that it's confusing for the consumers.

Comment: I'm afraid I have to take issue with you there, Alexandra. Catholic liturgy has always taken into account the fact that we humans have bodies with which to apprehend and respond to the world around us. That being the case, at various points in the mass we're required to sit, stand, or kneel, depending on the liturgical action. Sitting is the most passive posture of the three and the one that demands the least from us. Kneeling denotes humility and so is appropriate for those points in the mass in which our corporate prayer is the most intense, as in the eucharistic prayer. But in standing our bodies are the most alive - we're free to move, stretch, our blood is flowing more and oxygen is getting to the brain faster - all of which engages us more deeply with the liturgical action. When sitting it is easier to get lulled into a sense of complacency. These days it seems to spur distracted people to look at their cell phones, so there's something to be said for more standing, I think.

Comment: Besides being subject to Nondisclosure Agreements, Comey falls under federal laws governing the disclosure of classified and nonclassified information.  Assuming that the memos were not classified (though it seems odd that it would not be classified even on the confidential level), there is 18 U.S.C. § 641 which makes it a crime to steal, sell, or convey “any record, voucher, money, or thing of value of the United States or of any department or agency thereof.”

There are also ethical and departmental rules against the use of material to damage a former represented person or individual or firm related to prior representation. The FBI website states:

    Dissemination of FBI information is made strictly in accordance with provisions of the Privacy Act; Title 5, United States Code, Section 552a; FBI policy and procedures regarding discretionary release of information in accordance with the Privacy Act; and other applicable federal orders and directives.”

Comment: It is true that the scale of a farm doesn't determine its quality.  In fact, smaller farms often times use more energy and produce more greenhouse gases  However, the fact remains that the process of raising animals for food is very resource intensive, requiring massive amounts of water and energy while creating massive amount of pollution. And while some farms treat cows, pigs, chickens, etc, better than others, they are all eventually killed after living short miserable lives. 

If we are serious about conservation and climate change we will transition as quickly as possible to a mostly plant-based food system.  The transition will come sooner or later whether we like it or not.  We have an opportunity to do it voluntarily in a more cost effective responsible way rather than waiting until we've further depleted the planets finite resources and further polluted the land, air. and water.

I applaud the authors of this piece for trying to improve their unsustainable unhealthy business.

Comment: After viewing Obama's last Press Conference yesterday, his farewell speech, his other talks and interviews in recent weeks, I feel a profound sense of both gratitude and of  loss.  This is the ending of the Presidency of a man and his wife and children who possess such dignity, such thoughtfulness and class, who have modeled outstanding restraint in the face of the most awful and shocking degradation all built on the racism that still runs so deep in America, and who leaves us a legacy he can be very proud of, as many of us are, while also acknowledging that not all went well and that he, as all of us, can be disappointed in our own human failings and shortcomings.  I have had some similar feelings about our past Presidents, each of whom seem to have grown in these recognitions by the time their time in the Oval Office comes to its conclusion - but none of them with the power and clarity and simple honesty as Mr. Obama.  Will this be the case with our next POTUS? I have seen a clue...

Comment: This article is book ended by some legitimate concerns about sexual harassment in tech, but the stuff about meritocracy sandwiched in the middle is pretty disturbing.

You can't say something isn't a meritocracy just because it doesn't accurately reflect population demographics.  The NBA is a meritocracy, and it's mostly black with some Eastern and Southern Europeans thrown in. In general, white North Americans, Latinos and Asians don't have much representation....but that didn't stop Jeremy Lin or Steve Nash or Yao Ming or Manu Ginobli. The NBA is a meritocracy - if you can play, you're in.

The examples cited to 'disprove' that this is a meritocracy, don't do that at all. There is no control - they basically just say that this is not a meritocracy because it's mostly male and mostly white, without proving that non-male non-whites are any better. If you want to argue that lack of diversity is a problem, that's fair...but that is irrelevant to the concept of a meritocracy.

Comment: DC,

Because those are just statements of opinion, not facts.  There is no evidence of cause and effect provided.  The one (expelled) to three (stayed) ratio provided is actually evidence that the opposite may (notice the word may) be true.  Instead of the mythical apartheid racist state that many folks strain to prove with scant real evidence, we have evidence of white citizens defending black citizen's rights to live in Oregon when it is clearly against the law and the law not being enforced by said racist government!  No tar and feathering, no running out on a rail, no lynchings (though I think I do vaguely remember reading about the possibility of a mock lynching).  It seems to me "Oregon racism" is far more smoke being blown than fire.  But if it makes one feel good to feel guilty about policies and events that one had nothing to do with or believes and ended almost a hundred years ago, go ahead and feel good.  Just don't expect everyone else to get all worked-up about it.
